<p><strong><em>We definitely </em></strong><em>see an advantage for B2C start-ups</em><em> in the United States, as investors and teams there are much bolder and relentlessly invest in growth. In B2B, however, European start-ups are excelling due to what we see as the region’s technological advantage and the early value creation that comes from customer relationships.
<br>
</em>—Hendrik Brandis, Earlybird Venture Capital</p>
<p>The European start-up landscape has for quite some time been best known for the success of B2C start-ups such as Deliveroo, FlixBus, and Revolut. In recent years, however, a handful of European B2B start-ups have achieved valuations of $1 billion—and a few have even reached the coveted $10 billion status—but mostly outside the public eye. Personio, sennder, UiPath, and Klarna (which is both B2B and B2C) are among the most notable, and several others B2B start-ups, such as KONUX and Forto, are well on their way.</p>
<p>This handful of current and soon-to-be European dynamos are just the most visible part of the strong and growing wave of high-performing B2B start-ups that are making the entrepreneurial scene in Europe much more competitive and attractive for investors. The B2B start-up space in Europe, in fact, might now be in a position to innovate on par with its peer in the United States.</p>

class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><h4>Three assets of the B2B landscape in Europe fuel its growth potential: </h4>
<ul>
    <li><em>Great value for money:</em><strong> </strong>European B2B start-ups<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="e552d518-b392-4a03-96e0-0ad37b3e3880"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="e552d518-b392-4a03-96e0-0ad37b3e3880" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">The term European start-ups refers to EU-based start-ups; UK-based start-ups have been excluded from this research.</span></span></span></a></span> produce more output relative to their funding levels; revenue and valuations per invested dollar are higher than in the United States.</li>
    <li><em>Mature regional ecosystem:</em><strong> </strong>The key ingredients for success—talent, funding, and business partners—are available. </li>
    <li><em>Fertile ground:</em> The European economy’s need for innovation will likely further improve B2B start-ups’ conditions for growth. </li>
</ul>
<h4>Calls to action for the ecosystem’s key stakeholders:</h4>
<ul>
    <li><em>Founders</em> should seize the opportunity from a quickly growing ecosystem and increasing investor interest to take ambitious steps forward.</li>
    <li><em>Investors</em> should act on the potential to move more aggressively into the B2B start-up market yet provide their investments with the necessary expertise to increase the chance of success.</li>
    <li><em>Corporates</em> should engage with start-ups across all phases to help both the start-ups and themselves.</li>
</ul></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>To shed light on the rise of B2B start-ups in Europe and the implications of this growth on the overall start-up ecosystem in Europe, we conducted a course of quantitative and qualitative research. Among our key findings is that European B2B start-ups produce more output relative to their funding levels—revenue and valuations per invested dollar are higher than in the United States—and Europe’s mature, regional ecosystem is fertile ground for B2B start-up innovation and success (see sidebars, “Key insights” and “About the research”).</p>
<h2>Success and potential of B2B start-ups in Europe</h2>
<p>Three factors are likely to boost the growth potential of B2B start-ups in Europe: first, they provide great value for money; second, they profit from a mature regional ecosystem; and third, the European business landscape with its need for innovation is fertile ground for growing new innovation champions.</p>
<h3>Great value for money: European B2B start-ups outperform their US-based peers in value per invested capital</h3>
<p><em>We are seeing great value for money in the European B2B start-up landscape. That is why we have been establishing our fund.
<br>
</em>—Alexander Kudlich, 468 Capital</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="light" data-module-background="lightest-grey" data-module-category="" data-module-gradient-position="bottom-right" data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-u-ts-3 SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-heading__NJekY"><div>About the research</div></h2><div class="SideBar_mck-c-sidebar__content-description__4p9iI mdc-u-ts-7"><div class="mdc-o-content-body"><p><strong>The insights in this article</strong> were derived from quantitative analyses based on  the following Crunchbase data set:</p>
<ul>
    <li>more than 130,000 companies founded from 2010 to 2020 in Europe and the United States, out of which approximately 77,900 are B2B start-ups<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="ea5c5a7a-0f2f-4fdc-afc8-478a417b01ce"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="ea5c5a7a-0f2f-4fdc-afc8-478a417b01ce" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">We classified the companies manually and based on specific keywords since the Crunchbase data do not contain such a characterization.</span></span></span></a></span> and approximately 56,600 are B2C start-ups</li>
    <li>more than 85,000 recorded funding rounds, out of which approximately 70,000 specified the funding stage for example, seed, series A, B, C, D, and later-stage</li>
    <li>more than 30,000 investors from all around the world who have actively been investing in start-ups founded between 2010 and 2020 in Europe and the United States</li>
</ul>
<p>In addition, interviews with approximately 20 investors and founders of European B2B start-ups were conducted in  January and February 2021.</p></div></div></div></div></div></div>
<p>The <a href="/industries/technology-media-and-telecommunications/our-insights/europes-start-up-ecosystem-heating-up-but-still-facing-challenges">European start-up sector</a> has long stood in the shadow of its US cousin. For most of the last few decades, almost all of the world’s major innovations have seemed to originate in the large venture clusters of Silicon Valley, San Francisco, New York, and Boston. In recent years, however, the European start-up ecosystem has given birth to major start-up successes that stand out in comparison with those in the United States. Among these are Swedish payment provider Klarna, which brought vast innovation to e-commerce, and UiPath, a process-automation company launched in 2005 in Romania, now valued at more than $10 billion. Other examples include the process-mining company Celonis, the HR-software company Personio, and digital freight-forwarding company sender.</p>
<p>All these companies have achieved billion-dollar valuations, and many more European start-ups will likely follow suit. Beyond the most well-known examples, the broader B2B sector in Europe is experiencing very strong development and is now at least on pace with the B2B start-up sector in the United States.</p>
<p>Examining data on the past ten years in detail, we find that European B2B start-ups are outperforming their US counterparts in funding efficiency—that is, they generate more value (for example, revenue, external valuation) per invested capital. European B2B start-ups generate, on average, approximately 2.4 times the revenue per dollar invested compared with US-based B2B start-ups (Exhibit 1). The difference in revenue per invested capital is less pronounced for B2C start-ups but still significant: European start-ups generate about 1.2 times more revenue per dollar invested than their US counterparts.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 1</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/technology%20media%20and%20telecommunications/high%20tech/our%20insights/europes%20innovation%20wunderkinds%20the%20rising%20b2b%20startup%20ecosystem/svgz-wunderkindb2b-ex1.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="European B2B start-ups have better funding efficiency than their US and B2C counterparts, generating more value per invested capital" src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/technology%20media%20and%20telecommunications/high%20tech/our%20insights/europes%20innovation%20wunderkinds%20the%20rising%20b2b%20startup%20ecosystem/svgz-wunderkindb2b-ex1.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. <!-- -->
<p>We observe a similar trend—though less pronounced—when examining the valuation-to-investment ratio: European B2B start-ups show an approximately 10 percent higher ratio compared with US-based B2B start-ups. Along this metric, European B2B start-ups also outperform European B2C start-ups.</p>
<p>There are several possible reasons for this disparity. First, European B2B founders came of age in an environment where capital was, at least until now, significantly less abundant than it was for their US counterparts. This reality likely engendered a more conservative expectation around fundraising, which might prove especially useful in regions without an established venture capital (VC) infrastructure and less of a tradition of private-sector investment in start-ups (Eastern Europe, for instance).</p>
<p>At the same time, the cost base in Europe is more favorable when it comes to several of the characteristics most relevant to start-ups. For example, several professional skill profiles critical to B2B start-ups (such as software developers) are often less costly in Europe than in many regions in the United States. Additionally, office rents in metropolitan locations in Europe are often lower compared with the start-up hot-spot regions in the United States.</p>
<p>Comparing different regions in Europe, we observe that the funding efficiency (revenue per total amount of funding) is indeed higher in regions in Eastern and Southern European countries, where funding is least abundant (Exhibit 2). By contrast, the largest European start-up ecosystems in Germany and France have the lowest revenue-per-funding ratios in Europe; nevertheless, they still generate about 1.5 times more revenue per dollar invested than B2B start-ups in the United States.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 2</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/technology%20media%20and%20telecommunications/high%20tech/our%20insights/europes%20innovation%20wunderkinds%20the%20rising%20b2b%20startup%20ecosystem/svgz-wunderkindb2b-ex2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="B2B start-ups in less developed parts of Europe boast higher capital efficiency than those in Germany or France, but all EU regions outdo the United States." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/technology%20media%20and%20telecommunications/high%20tech/our%20insights/europes%20innovation%20wunderkinds%20the%20rising%20b2b%20startup%20ecosystem/svgz-wunderkindb2b-ex2.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>When examining start-up growth potential in different sectors, Europe seems to have a great opportunity to develop a spike in industrial and technological applications, given the continent’s strong industrial heritage. Capital efficiency is particularly pronounced in typical B2B tech industries such as aerospace, analytics, biotech, energy, enterprise software, and robotics. European start-ups in this space deliver more revenue per invested dollars than their US counterparts (Exhibit 3), and shifting priorities triggered by the COVID-19 pandemic could support their growth even further. In contrast, European start-ups in typical B2C industries (for example, e-commerce, food, social media) are delivering about the same value for funding as US-based B2C start-ups.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 3</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/technology%20media%20and%20telecommunications/high%20tech/our%20insights/europes%20innovation%20wunderkinds%20the%20rising%20b2b%20startup%20ecosystem/svgz-wunderkindb2b-ex3.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="EU start-ups in B2B domains outperform US peers in capital efficiency." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/technology%20media%20and%20telecommunications/high%20tech/our%20insights/europes%20innovation%20wunderkinds%20the%20rising%20b2b%20startup%20ecosystem/svgz-wunderkindb2b-ex3.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p><em>The European B2B start-up scene is growing significantly and, from an investor perspective, often providing great value for money given a stronger focus and mindset on capital efficiency and lower operating costs—for example, for software developers—than in the United States.</em>
<br>
—Felix Haas, 10X Group</p>
<h3>Mature regional ecosystem: The key ingredients for B2B start-ups’ success are readily available in Europe</h3>
<p><em>Back in 2015, the B2B start-up ecosystem in Europe was lacking experienced founders, investors, and corporate collaborators. Now this has changed, and we see the success with multiple multibillion-dollar companies.
<br>
</em>—Alexander Kudlich, 468 Capital</p>
<p>Critical ingredients for the success of start-ups are becoming more obtainable in Europe, namely funding, talent and mindset, and an ecosystem of peers and partners.</p>
<h3>Funding</h3>
<p><em>When we wanted to close a series A funding in 2016, we really struggled to find enough investors in Europe, particularly in Germany. This has now changed. For our series C round in January 2021, it has been relatively easy to raise money—although we were pretty selective in terms of the competencies we were looking for in new partners.
<br>
</em>—Andreas Kunze, KONUX</p>
<p>Overall, start-ups have an easier time acquiring funding in the United States. That is particularly true in the B2B space, where the underlying technology and business models are often more complex than in the B2C space, requiring investors to bring more expertise to the table. The median equity funding for a B2B start-up in the United States is 2.7 times the median funding for a B2B start-up in Europe. For B2C start-ups, that factor is only 1.5.</p>
<p>However, drilling down and segmenting by growth stage, we see a different picture: the further along a European start-up is in fundraising, the more comparable the amount of funding it receives is to what its US counterparts raise (Exhibit 4). In the seed and series A funding rounds, US B2B start-ups raise about 1.6 to 1.7 times the funding of European counterparts. By the time those same start-ups get to series C or later, however, that factor has decreased to 1.1.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 4</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/technology%20media%20and%20telecommunications/high%20tech/our%20insights/europes%20innovation%20wunderkinds%20the%20rising%20b2b%20startup%20ecosystem/svgz-wunderkindb2b-ex4.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Funding of EU B2B start-ups trails that of US peers early on, but the gap is narrowed in later stages." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/technology%20media%20and%20telecommunications/high%20tech/our%20insights/europes%20innovation%20wunderkinds%20the%20rising%20b2b%20startup%20ecosystem/svgz-wunderkindb2b-ex4.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>In the past five years, the number of growth-stage funding rounds for European B2B start-ups has grown by 123 percent and has not even decreased during the COVID-19 crisis. Prominent examples of larger growth-stage funding rounds during the crisis include the railway-software platform KONUX, the Berlin-based vertical-farming player Infarm, and the previously mentioned Personio. By contrast, in the United States, this number has only grown by 40 percent. That gap hardly exists for B2C start-up investments, with European growth-stage funding rounds up by 28 percent, compared with 22 percent for the United States.</p>
<p>This funding dynamic is fueled by both sides of the Atlantic. On the one hand, US investors are extremely interested in funding the growth stage (series C and later) of European B2B start-ups, accounting for almost a quarter of the total number of investors (Exhibit 5). But their interest in early-stage start-ups is also increasing: the share of US investors in European B2B seed-funding rounds has increased by 78 percent over the past five years. Recent examples of US investments in the seed stage of European start-ups include the German productivity player Layer, Finnish vertical-farming tech start-up iFarm, and the Portuguese fintech company Balancer Labs.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 5</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/technology%20media%20and%20telecommunications/high%20tech/our%20insights/europes%20innovation%20wunderkinds%20the%20rising%20b2b%20startup%20ecosystem/svgz-wunderkindb2b-ex5.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="Almost a quarter of growth-stage funding for EU B2B start-ups comes from  US investors, who are also increasingly contributing to seed funding." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/technology%20media%20and%20telecommunications/high%20tech/our%20insights/europes%20innovation%20wunderkinds%20the%20rising%20b2b%20startup%20ecosystem/svgz-wunderkindb2b-ex5.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>On the other hand, the European investment ecosystem itself is maturing. Along with the rise of specialized B2B investment funds and the inflow of growth-stage VC money, corporate investors are stepping up their game of investing in growth-stage start-ups. For example, last year, corporate VC investors participated in more than 210 percent more funding rounds (series A–C) than in 2015 (Exhibit 6). Another positive sign for the maturing investment ecosystem is the increasing number of B2B growth-stage rounds that included the participation of angel investors who are also cofounders in relatively new start-ups (225 percent increase during the past five years).</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 6</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/technology%20media%20and%20telecommunications/high%20tech/our%20insights/europes%20innovation%20wunderkinds%20the%20rising%20b2b%20startup%20ecosystem/svgz-wunderkindb2b-ex6.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="The growth in funding rounds for EU B2B start-ups is driven by an expanding  and maturing European investment ecosystem." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/technology%20media%20and%20telecommunications/high%20tech/our%20insights/europes%20innovation%20wunderkinds%20the%20rising%20b2b%20startup%20ecosystem/svgz-wunderkindb2b-ex6.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>One gap that remains to be closed, however, is the level of professionalization that established US investors typically bring to the table. While European investors are beginning to make more significant capital investments, they don’t yet have the decades of experience that would allow them also to share equally valuable tools, expertise, and best practices with start-ups.</p>
<p><em>Much more than the money invested, we largely benefited from the capabilities offered by our US investors along the value chain. The tool set we received from them and their help in professionalizing processes from recruiting to sales has been invaluable. And most European players do not just yet have the resources to offer something similar.<br>
</em>—André Christ, LeanIX</p>
<h3>Talent</h3>
<p>Along with the ability to acquire funding, talent is an equally important factor for the success of a venture. In contrast to many B2C areas, B2B often requires specific business expertise and, for many domains, a deep technological understanding. Several characteristics have made Europe an excellent source of such talent:</p>
<div data-module-category="" class="PullQuote_mck-c-pullquote__DbaQ5 mck-o-sm-left-span" style="transform: translate(0px, 35px); opacity: 0;"><blockquote data-component="mdc-c-blockquote" class="PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote__6n21p PullQuote_mck-c-blockquote--hide-quotes__CpGpg mdc-c-blockquote mdc-c-blockquote--is-quotes___TozKo_990311c"><p>Along with the ability to acquire funding, talent is an equally important factor for the success of a venture—B2B often requires specific business expertise and a deep technological understanding.</p></blockquote></div>
<ul>
    <li><em>Top-tier institutions.</em><strong> </strong>Europe has a high density of <a href="/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/how-growth-can-help-europes-companies-face-the-coming-economic-crisis">top-flight educational institutions</a>, putting its research base on an equally vaunted level with that of the United States. The challenge will be to cultivate a start-up environment in Europe that is as attractive to young talent—in creativity, opportunity, innovation, and compensation—as it is in the alluring start-up meccas of the United States.</li>
    <li><em>Deep industry expertise.</em> As the business culture in Europe shifts away from a singular focus on incumbent companies in traditional industries toward an appreciation for entrepreneurship, many “corporate type” professionals are now looking for ways to get involved in the start-up scene. These experts’ willingness to lend their knowledge and deep industry expertise is a significant resource for start-ups as they navigate the corporate environment.</li>
    <li><em>Bold entrepreneurial spirit.</em> European founders are increasingly characterized by a “think big” approach to entrepreneurship. This approach is evidenced by more and more early expansions beyond their borders (across Europe and even into the United States). Examples include Delivery Hero’s rapid global expansion, sender’s highly successful move into Italy, and LeanIX’s presence in the US market.</li>
    <li><em>Founders’ legacy.</em> The European start-up ecosystem has matured to yield a significant group of successful serial entrepreneurs, with 8.3 percent of recent B2B founders in Europe having founded at least one other venture.
    While this still lags behind the United States (11.5 percent), the gap is closing. This reality results in two specific assets moving forward: these founders are now bringing deep experience from past ventures into their own new B2B businesses, and they are also in a good position to nurture the B2B start-up ecosystem by mentoring and supporting other founders.</li>
</ul>
<h3>Ecosystem partners</h3>
<p><em>With its historically strong industrial and manufacturing sector, Germany offers not only a broad platform of potential customers for many B2B topics but also a great opportunity to establish reference cases as a springboard for internationalizing the offering.</em>
<br>
—Andreas Kunze, KONUX</p>
<p>Partnering with established companies is incredibly important for B2B start-ups. Incumbents not only are natural customers but also can be essential in helping to develop a product toward the optimal market fit. In the process, they can make it easier to find a critical mass of customers, or they could possibly even end up acquiring the venture.</p>
<p><a href="/capabilities/mckinsey-digital/our-insights/cant-buy-love-corporate-start-up-partnerships-in-the-dach-region">A survey among start-ups</a> from the DACH region (comprising the majority German-speaking countries of Germany, Austria, and Switzerland) has shown that B2B start-ups are especially interested in such partnerships and that they look for more than just the revenue boosts that accompany them. This rising enthusiasm is now being reciprocated on the corporate side, where a new generation of top management that understands the potential benefits of innovation for themselves seems more open to collaborating with start-ups.</p>
<p>The spirit of collaboration observable in US corporates is beginning to have a positive impact on the B2B start-up ecosystem in Europe. As more US tech companies open local offices and R&D centers in the region, the opportunities for EU B2B start-ups to collaborate or be acquired are growing.<span class="FootNote_footnote-holder__tjRqy"><a aria-label="footnote" href="javascript:void(0);" class="FootNote_footnote-wrapper__AIRwL undefined FootNote_inactive__VZfCp" aria-describedby="481b64af-b26e-4d87-903e-1fd461cedbce"><sup class="FootNote_footnotesup__e73z_">1</sup><span class="FootNote_notch-wrapper__b_5NS"><span class="FootNote_notch__omKtY"></span></span><span class="FootNote_tooltip__QtrbA mdc-u-mt-2"><span class="FootNote_footnote-content__r2OVl"><span id="481b64af-b26e-4d87-903e-1fd461cedbce" aria-hidden="true" data-module-theme="light" class="FootNote_footnote-text__VjKgO mck-u-links-inline">Maija Palmer, “Why do European companies buy so few startups?,” Sifted, August 11, 2020, sifted.eu.</span></span></span></a></span></p>
<p>Finally, as some European start-ups scale and mature, they become the type of resource to younger start-ups that their own corporate partners had been to them. One example is European e-commerce company Zalando. Beyond its product offerings in fashion and housewares to consumers, the 12-year-old company is now a platform that offers marketplace solutions for younger B2B start-ups.</p>
<h3>Fertile ground: The need for innovation in Europe’s economy will further improve B2B start-ups’ conditions for growing into innovation champions</h3>
<p>The European economy is in deep need of innovation. Given Europe’s relatively high wage structure and low reliance on natural resources, innovation remains of fundamental importance to the continent’s economic and social futures. Yet the share of European companies that consider themselves <a href="/featured-insights/innovation-and-growth/reviving-innovation-in-europe">true innovators</a> is notably lower than in the United States.</p>
<p>Disruptive technologies and new ways of working can be part of a transformation that helps Europe to strengthen its market position in an increasingly competitive global marketplace. The COVID-19 crisis has only added to this pressure to improve and reinvent how business is conducted. Start-ups are key in bringing innovation and its accompanying competitive advantage to all industries—from finance to deep tech. B2B start-ups in Europe could significantly uplift the modernizing of the European economy by partnering with and selling their products to established companies.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-disruptor1up mck-o-md-center mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom mck-u-screen-only" data-layer-region="disruptor-1up"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-md mdc-u-grid-col-lg-12 mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 "><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-12"><header data-component="mdc-c-header" class="mdc-c-header"><div class="mdc-c-header__block___i1Lg-_990311c"><h3 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c"><div>Would you like to learn more about our <a href="/industries/technology-media-and-telecommunications/how-we-help-clients">Technology, Media & Telecommunications Practice</a>?</div></h3></div></header><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c mdc-c-link-container--display-column___X0HDD_990311c mck-c-disruptor1up__content Disruptor1Up_mck-c-disruptor1up__content--links__VV4lE mdc-u-grid-gutter-md"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" href="/industries/technology-media-and-telecommunications/how-we-help-clients/startups-venture-capital" class="mdc-c-link-cta___NBQVi_990311c"><span class="mdc-c-link__label___Pfqtd_990311c">Visit our Startups & Venture Capital page</span><span data-component="mdc-c-icon" class="mdc-c-icon___oi7ef_990311c mck-link-arrow-right-icon"></span></a></div></div></div></div>
<p>Beyond partnering and selling to established companies, B2B start-ups in Europe will also contribute to a new European economy just by growing in size themselves.</p>
<p>Unlike the B2C space in Europe—where start-ups must navigate different cultures of the different countries and their distinct consumer markets—the landscape of business customers is more homogeneous. Businesses across the continent still tend to follow more predictable and similar rules. Hence, a venture can be grown regionally or even globally more easily without having to spend so much time and resources adapting the product to specific local markets.</p>
<h2>Harnessing the opportunities of the European B2B start-up ecosystem: A call to action</h2>
<p>While funding opportunities have increased, it is still the case that European B2B start-ups obtain fewer funding rounds than their US counterparts (an average of 1.9 versus 2.5 for US peers), and only 27 percent of European B2B start-ups advance from seed to series A compared with 46 percent of their US peers (Exhibit 7).</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-inline-module-container mck-o-md-center"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-lg mdc-u-grid-col-sm-1 mdc-u-grid--align-start mdc-u-mb-3 GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__sGwKL"><div data-component="mdc-c-content-block" class="mdc-c-content-block___7p6Lu_990311c mdc-u-grid-gutter-xs GenericItem_mck-c-generic-item__content__gq1m0"><div class="mck-c-eyebrow mdc-u-ts-10"><span>Exhibit 7</span></div></div></div><div class="mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture" class="Exhibit_mck-c-exhibit__image__pyIDm"><source media="(min-width: 768px)" srcset="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/technology%20media%20and%20telecommunications/high%20tech/our%20insights/europes%20innovation%20wunderkinds%20the%20rising%20b2b%20startup%20ecosystem/svgz-wunderkindb2b-ex7.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center"><img alt="EU B2B start-ups fail earlier and more frequently than their US peers, while   the difference in B2C success rates is much less pronounced." src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/technology%20media%20and%20telecommunications/high%20tech/our%20insights/europes%20innovation%20wunderkinds%20the%20rising%20b2b%20startup%20ecosystem/svgz-wunderkindb2b-ex7.svgz?cq=50&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mck-u-sr-only">We strive to provide individuals with disabilities equal access to our website. If you would like information about this content we will be happy to work with you. Please email us at: <a href="mailto:McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com">McKinsey_Website_Accessibility@mckinsey.com</a></div></div>
<p>The timing of funding also plays a central role in start-up success. Not only do European-based start-ups get fewer funding rounds, but it also takes them longer to get there—on average, half a year longer to raise a series A or B than US B2B start-ups. <a href="/capabilities/mckinsey-digital/our-insights/cant-buy-love-corporate-start-up-partnerships-in-the-dach-region">Long corporate-decision timelines and rigid budget processes</a> are some of the reasons for this gap, but there are clear commitments that the start-ups themselves, their investors, and established companies in the space can make to move the entire European ecosystem forward.</p>
<h3>Start-ups and founders: Complement your strengths with investors’ and corporates’ expertise</h3>
<p>The rising amount of growth-stage funding rounds is a good sign for the fast-developing European B2B start-up scene. This trend should encourage founders to stay ambitious and focus on scaling their companies. Meanwhile, the growing share of US investments is also sending a strong signal and comes with practical advantages for start-ups. As more US investors enter the market, European founders will not only have better access to growth-stage funding but also can leverage US investors to enter the US market earlier.</p>
<p>Attention is growing from not only foreign investors but also European corporates that need to boost innovation and are finally opening up to investing in or partnering with start-ups. That means that B2B start-ups and their founders do not necessarily have to move into attractive but expensive and crowded start-up hubs such as the United States to be closer to promising markets. Instead, they can leverage the higher efficiency and unchallenged access to talent in their home markets while being able to scale together with European corporates.</p>
<h3>Investors: Leverage your expertise</h3>
<p>Europe is a clear winner when it comes to value-for-money investments. That is especially true in B2B, where start-ups show great resource efficiency and technological know-how and the market is not yet overrun by investors competing for the same deals. The increased attention from US investors is overall a positive trend for all investors, as the influx of capital increases the value of the target start-ups.</p>
<p>With that being said, the law of diminishing returns applies here. Some foreign investment is an asset for potential European investors, but if it accelerates while the majority of European investors remain on the sidelines, the funding opportunities for them will be harder to come by. More European investors need to commit to growth-stage funding to be able to maintain the upward trend of catching up with (or even overtaking) their US counterparts.</p>
<div data-component="mdc-c-module-wrapper" data-module-theme="default" data-module-background="transparent" data-module-category="" class="mck-c-disruptor1up mck-o-md-center mck-u-inline-module-border-top mck-u-inline-module-border-bottom mck-u-screen-only" data-layer-region="disruptor-1up"><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-md mdc-u-grid-col-lg-12 mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 "><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-lg-span-4 mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-5 Disruptor1Up_mck-c-disruptor1up__image___2Gc4"><picture data-component="mdc-c-picture"><img alt="Europe’s start-up ecosystem: Heating up, but still facing challenges" src="/~/media/mckinsey/industries/technology%20media%20and%20telecommunications/high%20tech/our%20insights/europes%20start%20up%20ecosystem%20heating%20up%20but%20still%20facing%20challenges/europe-start-up-1536x1536.jpg?cq=50&mh=145&car=16:9&cpy=Center" loading="lazy"></picture></div><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-lg-span-8 mdc-u-grid-col-md-span-7"><header data-component="mdc-c-header" class="mdc-c-header"><div class="mdc-c-header__block___i1Lg-_990311c"><h3 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c"><div>Europe’s start-up ecosystem: Heating up, but still facing challenges</div></h3></div></header><div data-component="mdc-c-link-container" class="mdc-c-link-container___xefGu_990311c mdc-c-link-container--display-column___X0HDD_990311c mck-c-disruptor1up__content Disruptor1Up_mck-c-disruptor1up__content--links__VV4lE mdc-u-grid-gutter-md"><a data-component="mdc-c-link" href="/industries/technology-media-and-telecommunications/our-insights/europes-start-up-ecosystem-heating-up-but-still-facing-challenges" class="mdc-c-link-cta___NBQVi_990311c"><span class="mdc-c-link__label___Pfqtd_990311c">Read the article</span><span data-component="mdc-c-icon" class="mdc-c-icon___oi7ef_990311c mck-link-arrow-right-icon"></span></a></div></div></div></div>
<p>Yet investments should mean more than an injection of capital. Especially in the B2B sector, deep expertise from investors is necessary to support the ventures’ growth. Hence, investors should focus on a few selected domains and expand their teams with suitable experts.</p>
<p><em>To substantially grow this sector and become competitive with the United States, we need four to five large funds in Europe that are able to raise more than $1 billion. We need the capacity to fund
a $100 million series B round.</em>
<br>
—Hendrik Brandis, Earlybird Venture Capital</p>
<h3>Corporates: Develop start-ups as true partners</h3>
<p>The European B2B sector is thriving and innovating at great speed, which comes with a huge opportunity for European corporates. However, to realize the potential benefits, established companies in Europe will need to move more boldly into the start-up landscape. Many US tech titans have shown that these strategies can be highly successful, incorporating a significant number of start-ups over time—some of which have contributed core products to the product portfolio.</p>
<p>There is a great opportunity for corporates to support start-ups from the beginning, shape the products to their needs through codevelopment, and thus create innovation pipelines that do not require building an expensive corporate VC infrastructure. Getting there, however, requires corporate top management to be less hesitant about partnering with start-ups in the first place.</p>
<hr>
<p>Europe is beginning to stake a sizable claim in the start-up world. While it is the VC and innovation centers in the United States that still dominate in the B2C sphere, Europe’s B2B start-up ecosystem has unique strengths that could set the stage for the type of success that is defined not only by revenue at the individual level but also by innovation that benefits the entire regional economy. To realize this potential, however, both corporates and investors in the region need to understand the mutual interest in the success of Europe’s B2B ecosystem and partner with and invest in start-ups to make that a reality.</p></div><div class="container-placeholder"></div></div></div><div class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-gutter-xl"><section role="contentinfo" data-layer-region="article-about-authors" class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 AboutAuthor_mck-c-about-author__nRJzu"><div class="mdc-u-grid-col-md-start-2 mdc-u-grid-col-md-end-12 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-start-3 mdc-u-grid-col-lg-end-11"><h5 data-component="mdc-c-heading" class="mdc-c-heading___0fM1W_990311c mdc-c-heading--title___5qyOB_990311c mdc-c-heading--border___K8dj3_990311c mdc-u-align-center">About the author(s)</h5><div data-component="mdc-c-description" class="mdc-c-description___SrnQP_990311c mdc-u-ts-8 mck-u-links-inline mck-u-links-inline--secondary mdc-u-mt-5"><div><p><strong><a href="/our-people/karel-dorner">Karel Dörner</a> </strong>and <strong><a href="/our-people/max-flototto">Max Flötotto</a></strong> are senior partners in McKinsey’s Munich office, where <strong>Tobias Henz</strong> is an associate partner; <strong>Tobias Strålin</strong> is a partner in the Stockholm office.</p>
<p>The authors wish to thank Patrick Gassmann, Thomas Gersdorf, Jörg Hanebrink, Philipp Hühne, Michael Müller-Peltzer, and  KJ Ward for their contributions to this article.</p>
<hr>
<p>This article was edited by Daniel Eisenberg, a senior editor in the New York office.</p></div></div></div></section><section class="mdc-u-grid mdc-u-grid-col-md-12 mck-u-screen-only"><div front-runners can lead on AI in Europe</div></a></h6></div></div></div></div></div></div></div></main><div class="mck-u-sr-only" role="log" aria-live="polite" aria-relevant="additions" aria-atomic="true"></div></div><script id="__NEXT_DATA__" type="application/json">{"props":{"pageProps":{"locale":"en","dictionary":{},"sitecoreContext":{"route":{"name":"Europes innovation wunderkinds The rising B2B startup ecosystem","displayName":"Europes innovation wunderkinds The rising B2B startup ecosystem","fields":null,"databaseName":"web","deviceId":"fe5d7fdf-89c0-4d99-9aa3-b5fbd009c9f3","itemId":"5dbbcc93-be6b-47a6-94dd-d9cabb25941f","itemLanguage":"en","itemVersion":1,"layoutId":"ae753eb4-a035-40b4-83bf-4b4438df6742","templateId":"683910db-02ba-40ba-92e7-726c880160a9","templateName":"ArticleJSS","placeholders":{"jss-main":[{"uid":"232bb7e9-289f-492d-a916-2b6185e44a84","componentName":"ArticleTemplate","dataSource":"","fields":{"data":{"articleTemplate":{"title":{"jsonValue":{"value":"Europe\u0026rsquo;s innovation wunderkinds: The rising B2B start-up ecosystem"}},"sEOTitle":{"value":"Europe\u0026rsquo;s startups: New B2B companies on the rise"},"description":{"jsonValue":{"value":"While B2B start-ups are making Europe more competitive, start-ups, investors, and corporates will need to share expertise and work as partners to realize the region\u0026rsquo;s full entrepreneurial potential."}},"sEODescription":{"value":"While Europe’s B2B start-ups are becoming competitive, start-ups, investors, and corporates will need to share expertise and work as partners to realize the region’s full entrepreneurial potential."},"displayDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2021-04-14T00:00:00Z"}},"body":{"value":"[[DownloadsSidebar]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e\u003cem\u003eWe definitely \u003c/em\u003e\u003c/strong\u003e\u003cem\u003esee an advantage for B2C start-ups\u003c/em\u003e\u003cem\u003e in the United States, as investors and teams there are much bolder and relentlessly invest in growth. In B2B, however, European start-ups are excelling due to what we see as the region\u0026rsquo;s technological advantage and the early value creation that comes from customer relationships.\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003c/em\u003e\u0026mdash;Hendrik Brandis, Earlybird Venture Capital\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe European start-up landscape has for quite some time been best known for the success of B2C start-ups such as Deliveroo, FlixBus, and Revolut. In recent years, however, a handful of European B2B start-ups have achieved valuations of $1 billion\u0026mdash;and a few have even reached the coveted $10 billion status\u0026mdash;but mostly outside the public eye. Personio, sennder, UiPath, and Klarna (which is both B2B and B2C) are among the most notable, and several others B2B start-ups, such as KONUX and Forto, are well on their way.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis handful of current and soon-to-be European dynamos are just the most visible part of the strong and growing wave of high-performing B2B start-ups that are making the entrepreneurial scene in Europe much more competitive and attractive for investors. The B2B start-up space in Europe, in fact, might now be in a position to innovate on par with its peer in the United States.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Sidebar 2]]\n\u003cp\u003eTo shed light on the rise of B2B start-ups in Europe and the implications of this growth on the overall start-up ecosystem in Europe, we conducted a course of quantitative and qualitative research. Among our key findings is that European B2B start-ups produce more output relative to their funding levels\u0026mdash;revenue and valuations per invested dollar are higher than in the United States\u0026mdash;and Europe\u0026rsquo;s mature, regional ecosystem is fertile ground for B2B start-up innovation and success (see sidebars, \u0026ldquo;Key insights\u0026rdquo; and \u0026ldquo;About the research\u0026rdquo;).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eSuccess and potential of B2B start-ups in Europe\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThree factors are likely to boost the growth potential of B2B start-ups in Europe: first, they provide great value for money; second, they profit from a mature regional ecosystem; and third, the European business landscape with its need for innovation is fertile ground for growing new innovation champions.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eGreat value for money: European B2B start-ups outperform their US-based peers in value per invested capital\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eWe are seeing great value for money in the European B2B start-up landscape. That is why we have been establishing our fund.\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003c/em\u003e\u0026mdash;Alexander Kudlich, 468 Capital\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Sidebar 1]]\n\u003cp\u003eThe \u003ca href=\"/industries/technology-media-and-telecommunications/our-insights/europes-start-up-ecosystem-heating-up-but-still-facing-challenges\"\u003eEuropean start-up sector\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;has long stood in the shadow of its US cousin. For most of the last few decades, almost all of the world\u0026rsquo;s major innovations have seemed to originate in the large venture clusters of Silicon Valley, San Francisco, New York, and Boston. In recent years, however, the European start-up ecosystem has given birth to major start-up successes that stand out in comparison with those in the United States. Among these are Swedish payment provider Klarna, which brought vast innovation to e-commerce, and UiPath, a process-automation company launched in 2005 in Romania, now valued at more than $10 billion. Other examples include the process-mining company Celonis, the HR-software company Personio, and digital freight-forwarding company sender.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAll these companies have achieved billion-dollar valuations, and many more European start-ups will likely follow suit. Beyond the most well-known examples, the broader B2B sector in Europe is experiencing very strong development and is now at least on pace with the B2B start-up sector in the United States.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eExamining data on the past ten years in detail, we find that European B2B start-ups are outperforming their US counterparts in funding efficiency\u0026mdash;that is, they generate more value (for example, revenue, external valuation) per invested capital. European B2B start-ups generate, on average, approximately 2.4 times the revenue per dollar invested compared with US-based B2B start-ups (Exhibit 1). The difference in revenue per invested capital is less pronounced for B2C start-ups but still significant: European start-ups generate about 1.2 times more revenue per dollar invested than their US counterparts.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 1]]\n[[MostPopularArticles 5]]\n\u003cp\u003eWe observe a similar trend\u0026mdash;though less pronounced\u0026mdash;when examining the valuation-to-investment ratio: European B2B start-ups show an approximately 10 percent higher ratio compared with US-based B2B start-ups. Along this metric, European B2B start-ups also outperform European B2C start-ups.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThere are several possible reasons for this disparity. First, European B2B founders came of age in an environment where capital was, at least until now, significantly less abundant than it was for their US counterparts. This reality likely engendered a more conservative expectation around fundraising, which might prove especially useful in regions without an established venture capital (VC) infrastructure and less of a tradition of private-sector investment in start-ups (Eastern Europe, for instance).\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAt the same time, the cost base in Europe is more favorable when it comes to several of the characteristics most relevant to start-ups. For example, several professional skill profiles critical to B2B start-ups (such as software developers) are often less costly in Europe than in many regions in the United States. Additionally, office rents in metropolitan locations in Europe are often lower compared with the start-up hot-spot regions in the United States.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eComparing different regions in Europe, we observe that the funding efficiency (revenue per total amount of funding) is indeed higher in regions in Eastern and Southern European countries, where funding is least abundant (Exhibit 2). By contrast, the largest European start-up ecosystems in Germany and France have the lowest revenue-per-funding ratios in Europe; nevertheless, they still generate about 1.5 times more revenue per dollar invested than B2B start-ups in the United States.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 2]]\n\u003cp\u003eWhen examining start-up growth potential in different sectors, Europe seems to have a great opportunity to develop a spike in industrial and technological applications, given the continent\u0026rsquo;s strong industrial heritage. Capital efficiency is particularly pronounced in typical B2B tech industries such as aerospace, analytics, biotech, energy, enterprise software, and robotics. European start-ups in this space deliver more revenue per invested dollars than their US counterparts (Exhibit 3), and shifting priorities triggered by the COVID-19 pandemic could support their growth even further. In contrast, European start-ups in typical B2C industries (for example, e-commerce, food, social media) are delivering about the same value for funding as US-based B2C start-ups.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 3]]\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eThe European B2B start-up scene is growing significantly and, from an investor perspective, often providing great value for money given a stronger focus and mindset on capital efficiency and lower operating costs\u0026mdash;for example, for software developers\u0026mdash;than in the United States.\u003c/em\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u0026mdash;Felix Haas, 10X Group\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eMature regional ecosystem: The key ingredients for B2B start-ups\u0026rsquo; success are readily available in Europe\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eBack in 2015, the B2B start-up ecosystem in Europe was lacking experienced founders, investors, and corporate collaborators. Now this has changed, and we see the success with multiple multibillion-dollar companies.\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003c/em\u003e\u0026mdash;Alexander Kudlich, 468 Capital\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eCritical ingredients for the success of start-ups are becoming more obtainable in Europe, namely funding, talent and mindset, and an ecosystem of peers and partners.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eFunding\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eWhen we wanted to close a series A funding in 2016, we really struggled to find enough investors in Europe, particularly in Germany. This has now changed. For our series C round in January 2021, it has been relatively easy to raise money\u0026mdash;although we were pretty selective in terms of the competencies we were looking for in new partners.\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003c/em\u003e\u0026mdash;Andreas Kunze, KONUX\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eOverall, start-ups have an easier time acquiring funding in the United States. That is particularly true in the B2B space, where the underlying technology and business models are often more complex than in the B2C space, requiring investors to bring more expertise to the table. The median equity funding for a B2B start-up in the United States is 2.7 times the median funding for a B2B start-up in Europe. For B2C start-ups, that factor is only 1.5.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eHowever, drilling down and segmenting by growth stage, we see a different picture: the further along a European start-up is in fundraising, the more comparable the amount of funding it receives is to what its US counterparts raise (Exhibit 4). In the seed and series A funding rounds, US B2B start-ups raise about 1.6 to 1.7 times the funding of European counterparts. By the time those same start-ups get to series C or later, however, that factor has decreased to 1.1.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 4]]\n\u003cp\u003eIn the past five years, the number of growth-stage funding rounds for European B2B start-ups has grown by 123 percent and has not even decreased during the COVID-19 crisis. Prominent examples of larger growth-stage funding rounds during the crisis include the railway-software platform KONUX, the Berlin-based vertical-farming player Infarm, and the previously mentioned Personio. By contrast, in the United States, this number has only grown by 40 percent. That gap hardly exists for B2C start-up investments, with European growth-stage funding rounds up by 28 percent, compared with 22 percent for the United States.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThis funding dynamic is fueled by both sides of the Atlantic. On the one hand, US investors are extremely interested in funding the growth stage (series C and later) of European B2B start-ups, accounting for almost a quarter of the total number of investors (Exhibit 5). But their interest in early-stage start-ups is also increasing: the share of US investors in European B2B seed-funding rounds has increased by 78 percent over the past five years. Recent examples of US investments in the seed stage of European start-ups include the German productivity player Layer, Finnish vertical-farming tech start-up iFarm, and the Portuguese fintech company Balancer Labs.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 5]]\n\u003cp\u003eOn the other hand, the European investment ecosystem itself is maturing. Along with the rise of specialized B2B investment funds and the inflow of growth-stage VC money, corporate investors are stepping up their game of investing in growth-stage start-ups. For example, last year, corporate VC investors participated in more than 210 percent more funding rounds (series A\u0026ndash;C) than in 2015 (Exhibit 6). Another positive sign for the maturing investment ecosystem is the increasing number of B2B growth-stage rounds that included the participation of angel investors who are also cofounders in relatively new start-ups (225 percent increase during the past five years).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 6]]\n\u003cp\u003eOne gap that remains to be closed, however, is the level of professionalization that established US investors typically bring to the table. While European investors are beginning to make more significant capital investments, they don\u0026rsquo;t yet have the decades of experience that would allow them also to share equally valuable tools, expertise, and best practices with start-ups.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eMuch more than the money invested, we largely benefited from the capabilities offered by our US investors along the value chain. The tool set we received from them and their help in professionalizing processes from recruiting to sales has been invaluable. And most European players do not just yet have the resources to offer something similar.\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u003c/em\u003e\u0026mdash;Andr\u0026eacute; Christ, LeanIX\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eTalent\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAlong with the ability to acquire funding, talent is an equally important factor for the success of a venture. In contrast to many B2C areas, B2B often requires specific business expertise and, for many domains, a deep technological understanding. Several characteristics have made Europe an excellent source of such talent:\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Pullquote 1]]\n\u003cul\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eTop-tier institutions.\u003c/em\u003e\u003cstrong\u003e \u003c/strong\u003eEurope has a high density of \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/strategy-and-corporate-finance/our-insights/how-growth-can-help-europes-companies-face-the-coming-economic-crisis\"\u003etop-flight educational institutions\u003c/a\u003e, putting its research base on an equally vaunted level with that of the United States. The challenge will be to cultivate a start-up environment in Europe that is as attractive to young talent\u0026mdash;in creativity, opportunity, innovation, and compensation\u0026mdash;as it is in the alluring start-up meccas of the United States.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eDeep industry expertise.\u003c/em\u003e As the business culture in Europe shifts away from a singular focus on incumbent companies in traditional industries toward an appreciation for entrepreneurship, many \u0026ldquo;corporate type\u0026rdquo; professionals are now looking for ways to get involved in the start-up scene. These experts\u0026rsquo; willingness to lend their knowledge and deep industry expertise is a significant resource for start-ups as they navigate the corporate environment.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eBold entrepreneurial spirit.\u003c/em\u003e European founders are increasingly characterized by a \u0026ldquo;think big\u0026rdquo; approach to entrepreneurship. This approach is evidenced by more and more early expansions beyond their borders (across Europe and even into the United States). Examples include Delivery Hero\u0026rsquo;s rapid global expansion, sender\u0026rsquo;s highly successful move into Italy, and LeanIX\u0026rsquo;s presence in the US market.\u003c/li\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003e\u003cem\u003eFounders\u0026rsquo; legacy.\u003c/em\u003e The European start-up ecosystem has matured to yield a significant group of successful serial entrepreneurs, with 8.3 percent of recent B2B founders in Europe having founded at least one other venture.\n    While this still lags behind the United States (11.5 percent), the gap is closing. This reality results in two specific assets moving forward: these founders are now bringing deep experience from past ventures into their own new B2B businesses, and they are also in a good position to nurture the B2B start-up ecosystem by mentoring and supporting other founders.\u003c/li\u003e\n\u003c/ul\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eEcosystem partners\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eWith its historically strong industrial and manufacturing sector, Germany offers not only a broad platform of potential customers for many B2B topics but also a great opportunity to establish reference cases as a springboard for internationalizing the offering.\u003c/em\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u0026mdash;Andreas Kunze, KONUX\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003ePartnering with established companies is incredibly important for B2B start-ups. Incumbents not only are natural customers but also can be essential in helping to develop a product toward the optimal market fit. In the process, they can make it easier to find a critical mass of customers, or they could possibly even end up acquiring the venture.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003ca href=\"/capabilities/mckinsey-digital/our-insights/cant-buy-love-corporate-start-up-partnerships-in-the-dach-region\"\u003eA survey among start-ups\u003c/a\u003e from the DACH region (comprising the majority German-speaking countries of Germany, Austria, and Switzerland) has shown that B2B start-ups are especially interested in such partnerships and that they look for more than just the revenue boosts that accompany them. This rising enthusiasm is now being reciprocated on the corporate side, where a new generation of top management that understands the potential benefits of innovation for themselves seems more open to collaborating with start-ups.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe spirit of collaboration observable in US corporates is beginning to have a positive impact on the B2B start-up ecosystem in Europe. As more US tech companies open local offices and R\u0026amp;D centers in the region, the opportunities for EU B2B start-ups to collaborate or be acquired are growing.[[Footnote 1]]\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eFinally, as some European start-ups scale and mature, they become the type of resource to younger start-ups that their own corporate partners had been to them. One example is European e-commerce company Zalando. Beyond its product offerings in fashion and housewares to consumers, the 12-year-old company is now a platform that offers marketplace solutions for younger B2B start-ups.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eFertile ground: The need for innovation in Europe\u0026rsquo;s economy will further improve B2B start-ups\u0026rsquo; conditions for growing into innovation champions\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe European economy is in deep need of innovation. Given Europe\u0026rsquo;s relatively high wage structure and low reliance on natural resources, innovation remains of fundamental importance to the continent\u0026rsquo;s economic and social futures. Yet the share of European companies that consider themselves \u003ca href=\"/featured-insights/innovation-and-growth/reviving-innovation-in-europe\"\u003etrue innovators\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;is notably lower than in the United States.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eDisruptive technologies and new ways of working can be part of a transformation that helps Europe to strengthen its market position in an increasingly competitive global marketplace. The COVID-19 crisis has only added to this pressure to improve and reinvent how business is conducted. Start-ups are key in bringing innovation and its accompanying competitive advantage to all industries\u0026mdash;from finance to deep tech. B2B start-ups in Europe could significantly uplift the modernizing of the European economy by partnering with and selling their products to established companies.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Disruptor1UP dis1]]\n\u003cp\u003eBeyond partnering and selling to established companies, B2B start-ups in Europe will also contribute to a new European economy just by growing in size themselves.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eUnlike the B2C space in Europe\u0026mdash;where start-ups must navigate different cultures of the different countries and their distinct consumer markets\u0026mdash;the landscape of business customers is more homogeneous. Businesses across the continent still tend to follow more predictable and similar rules. Hence, a venture can be grown regionally or even globally more easily without having to spend so much time and resources adapting the product to specific local markets.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch2\u003eHarnessing the opportunities of the European B2B start-up ecosystem: A call to action\u003c/h2\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWhile funding opportunities have increased, it is still the case that European B2B start-ups obtain fewer funding rounds than their US counterparts (an average of 1.9 versus 2.5 for US peers), and only 27 percent of European B2B start-ups advance from seed to series A compared with 46 percent of their US peers (Exhibit 7).\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Exhibit 7]]\n\u003cp\u003eThe timing of funding also plays a central role in start-up success. Not only do European-based start-ups get fewer funding rounds, but it also takes them longer to get there\u0026mdash;on average, half a year longer to raise a series A or B than US B2B start-ups. \u003ca href=\"/capabilities/mckinsey-digital/our-insights/cant-buy-love-corporate-start-up-partnerships-in-the-dach-region\"\u003eLong corporate-decision timelines and rigid budget processes\u003c/a\u003e\u0026nbsp;are some of the reasons for this gap, but there are clear commitments that the start-ups themselves, their investors, and established companies in the space can make to move the entire European ecosystem forward.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eStart-ups and founders: Complement your strengths with investors\u0026rsquo; and corporates\u0026rsquo; expertise\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe rising amount of growth-stage funding rounds is a good sign for the fast-developing European B2B start-up scene. This trend should encourage founders to stay ambitious and focus on scaling their companies. Meanwhile, the growing share of US investments is also sending a strong signal and comes with practical advantages for start-ups. As more US investors enter the market, European founders will not only have better access to growth-stage funding but also can leverage US investors to enter the US market earlier.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eAttention is growing from not only foreign investors but also European corporates that need to boost innovation and are finally opening up to investing in or partnering with start-ups. That means that B2B start-ups and their founders do not necessarily have to move into attractive but expensive and crowded start-up hubs such as the United States to be closer to promising markets. Instead, they can leverage the higher efficiency and unchallenged access to talent in their home markets while being able to scale together with European corporates.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eInvestors: Leverage your expertise\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eEurope is a clear winner when it comes to value-for-money investments. That is especially true in B2B, where start-ups show great resource efficiency and technological know-how and the market is not yet overrun by investors competing for the same deals. The increased attention from US investors is overall a positive trend for all investors, as the influx of capital increases the value of the target start-ups.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eWith that being said, the law of diminishing returns applies here. Some foreign investment is an asset for potential European investors, but if it accelerates while the majority of European investors remain on the sidelines, the funding opportunities for them will be harder to come by. More European investors need to commit to growth-stage funding to be able to maintain the upward trend of catching up with (or even overtaking) their US counterparts.\u003c/p\u003e\n[[Disruptor1UP dis2]]\n\u003cp\u003eYet investments should mean more than an injection of capital. Especially in the B2B sector, deep expertise from investors is necessary to support the ventures\u0026rsquo; growth. Hence, investors should focus on a few selected domains and expand their teams with suitable experts.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003e\u003cem\u003eTo substantially grow this sector and become competitive with the United States, we need four to five large funds in Europe that are able to raise more than $1 billion. We need the capacity to fund\na $100 million series B round.\u003c/em\u003e\n\u003cbr /\u003e\n\u0026mdash;Hendrik Brandis, Earlybird Venture Capital\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003ch3\u003eCorporates: Develop start-ups as true partners\u003c/h3\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThe European B2B sector is thriving and innovating at great speed, which comes with a huge opportunity for European corporates. However, to realize the potential benefits, established companies in Europe will need to move more boldly into the start-up landscape. Many US tech titans have shown that these strategies can be highly successful, incorporating a significant number of start-ups over time\u0026mdash;some of which have contributed core products to the product portfolio.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eThere is a great opportunity for corporates to support start-ups from the beginning, shape the products to their needs through codevelopment, and thus create innovation pipelines that do not require building an expensive corporate VC infrastructure. Getting there, however, requires corporate top management to be less hesitant about partnering with start-ups in the first place.\u003c/p\u003e\n\u003chr /\u003e\n\u003cp\u003eEurope is beginning to stake a sizable claim in the start-up world. While it is the VC and innovation centers in the United States that still dominate in the B2C sphere, Europe\u0026rsquo;s B2B start-up ecosystem has unique strengths that could set the stage for the type of success that is defined not only by revenue at the individual level but also by innovation that benefits the entire regional economy. To realize this potential, however, both corporates and investors in the region need to understand the mutual interest in the success of Europe\u0026rsquo;s B2B ecosystem and partner with and invest in start-ups to make that a reality.\u003c/p\u003e"},"isFullScreenInteractive":{"boolValue":false},"hideStickySocialShareBar":{"boolValue":false},"desktopID":{"value":""},"mobileID":{"value":""},"desktopURL":{"value":""},"mobileURL":{"value":""},"desktopPaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"mobilePaddingPercentage":{"value":""},"desktopOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"mobileOverrideHeight":{"value":""},"cerosOembedURL":{"value":""},"cerosRenderMode":{"targetItem":null},"cerosBackgroundColor":{"targetItem":null},"hideByLine":{"boolValue":false},"tableOfContentsTitle":{"value":"TABLE OF CONTENTS"},"accessStatus":{"targetItem":{"key":{"value":"RegisteredUsers"},"value":{"value":"Registered Users"}}},"articleType":{"targetItem":{"displayName":"Article"}},"hasSpecialReport":{"boolValue":false},"contentType":{"targetItem":{"displayName":"Article"}},"sourcePublication":{"targetItem":null},"externalPublication":{"value":""},"mobileReady":{"boolValue":true},"forClientsOnly":{"boolValue":false},"excludeFromClientLink":{"boolValue":false},"originalPublishDate":{"jsonValue":{"value":"2021-04-14T00:00:00Z"}},"footnotes":{"value":"\u003col\u003e\n    \u003cli\u003eMaija Palmer, \u0026ldquo;Why do European companies buy so few startups?,\u0026rdquo;
